Matt Ittigson wrote:
> Some change in the code between earlier today and May 31st has caused
> a massive slowdown in the speed which I'm downloading data.  On the
> same machine, configured in the same way, a version of Heritrix I
> built from CVS, from earlier today, could not muster more than 30K/s
> on the same seed file that the May 31st version is currently doing
> 728K/s.
> 
> Perhaps the difference is in configuration?  Maybe I'm enabling a
> newer configuration variable which is slowing things down?  The
> difference between the order.xml files are only additions in the newer
> version:
> 
> reread-seeds-on-config: true
> use-bdb-for-cookies: true
> the universal extractor (with default configuration)
> LinkScoper instead of Postselector (with default configuration)
> 
> Would any of the log files be of use to track down the problem?

Depending on when you grabbed the code, there was a synchronization
bug that could corrupt a statistics HashMap, one possible symptom
of which was threads spinning in HashMap put() -- and thus also
soaking up cycles, slowing other threads.

Most useful for diagnosing this problem, and some others like it,
is the web UI threads report or a SIGQUIT JVM threads dump, plus
watching an OS tool like 'top'.

This particular problem is fixed... but keep in mind that CVS HEAD
is often 'bleeding edge'. Using it, you'll be subject to brand new
bugs -- up to and including things that render the crawler
inoperative until fixed.

If you use CVS HEAD, it can also be good to keep an eye on the
'archive-crawler-cvs' CVS commits mailing list -- so you see some
indication of big changes and latest fixes:

   http://sourceforge.net/mailarchive/forum.php?forum_id=34924

- Gordon @ IA
